Award.AwardTitle: Workshops for Chemistry Faculty of the 21st Century
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate new strategies to enhance the participation of chemistry faculty at minority-serving institutions (MSIs) in research supported by the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation. The primary activity of this award will be an annual workshop for faculty at these institutions to help them to develop competitive proposals for programs in the Chemistry Division. The overall goal is to cultivate research-active faculty at these institutions -- institutions that are responsible for the training of significant numbers of baccalaureate students from groups that have been underrepresented in the sciences.

In order to maintain its global competitiveness, the United States must work vigorously to tap neglected pools of intellectual talent. Students from underrepresented groups are, by definition, represented at lower rates than their fraction of the population. In academia, large fractions of B.S. level chemists from underrepresented groups, receive their training in minority-serving institutions, yet the funding for research at these institutions is low. This award will support the efforts of QEM to help faculty at these institutions develop competitive proposals for submission. The hope is to create a critical mass of research-active faculty at these institutions to guarantee that graduates from these institutions receive excellent training in modern chemical research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2010 through 2013, the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network, with support from National Science Foundation (NSF) Award #0935362, conducted three annual information and proposal development workshops for Chemistry faculty at minority-serving institutions (MSIs) to broaden their participation and success in the funding programs of NSF’s Division of Chemistry in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences. The award also provided supplementary support for 12 additional Chemistry faculty from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to participate in a Proposal Development Workshop for the NSF’s Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Award (RIA) strand in April 2013. A total of seventy (70) Chemistry faculty from MSIs participated in these workshops.  

Seventy faculty from MSIs received information regarding funding opportunities available through the Division of Chemistry for their research or through HBCU-UP to begin research in Chemistry. They received feedback and guidance from senior researchers on project summaries they prepared for Chemistry-based research and research initiation proposals.

Faculty participating in the workshops completed Workshop evaluation questionnaires on which they reported having a clearer understanding of the various programs offered through the NSF Division of Chemistry and HBCU-UP RIA.  They also reported feeling more confident that they could submit a competitive Chemistry research or research initiation proposal. Over 90 percent of the faculty participants indicated they planned to submit proposals in the next competition.

Of the 33 participants in the January 2011 and 2012 Chemistry Workshops, 21 responded to QEM follow-up surveys. Eight (8) participants (38 percent) submitted proposals to the Chemistry Division, while several others reported submissions to other NSF programs and other potential funders. Two of the eight faculty members who submitted proposals have received awards for a success rate of 25 percent. Thirty-seven (37) of the workshop participants, who attended the January 2013 Chemistry Proposal Workshop of the April 2013 RIA Proposal Workshop will have their first opportunity to submit proposals in Fall 2013

Broadening participation of Chemistry faculty at MSIs in NSF programs of the Division of Chemistry will provide chemists at MSIs with increased opportunity for chemistry-focused research support. This support, in turn, will provide Chemistry faculty with additional opportunities to increase their own scholarly productivity as well as enhance their teaching and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students in Chemistry. The talents and perspectives of a broader group of underrepresented minorities will enrich and energize the discipline of Chemistry.

The discipline of Chemistry is critical to the pursuit and attainment of society’s goals in a number of critical areas, including health, agriculture, environmental protection, energy, and security. Broadening participation of underrepresented minorities in Chemistry will provide the Nation with improved access to the insights, perspectives, and expertise needed to sustain and enhance our Nation’s competitiveness in the global economy and provide a high quality of life for all its citizens.
